Facebook Inc. FB, -1.58% said Tuesday that it plans to gives its 2.2 billion members the option of clearing their browsing history on the site, including what users have clicked on, and what sites they have visited.

At the company's F8 developer conference in San Jose, Calif., Zuckerberg said that since people can delete cookies and web history from their web browsers, he wants Facebook users to be able to do the same thing.
He also said that the new tool will work much the same way that clearing a web browser's cookie data and website browsing history work and will be called "Clear History."
The new feature comes in the wake of the scandal involving improperly handled Facebook data that was obtained by Cambridge Analytica.
Facebook stock has dropped nearly 3% this year, as the benchmark S&P 500 index SPX, -2.33% has fallen less than 1%.
Facebook stock is down less than 1% to $171.24 in early afternoon trading.
"We're working on a version of this for Facebook too," Zuckerberg said.
